awd_abstract_narration:
Identifying and understanding factors that improve human memory is one of the central aims of human memory research, with important societal implications for education, training, enhancing cognitive performance, and rehabilitating the memory-impaired. This project investigates a recently discovered means of improving memory known as the survival processing effect, whereby thinking about an item in terms of its potential survival utility in an imagined survival scenario greatly improves memory for that item relative to other known mnemonic techniques. This project is aimed at understanding why the survival processing benefit to memory occurs. Specifically, what are the underlying mechanisms responsible for the dramatic levels of memory improvement shown over other known memory-enhancing techniques? Is a deeply ingrained evolutionary basis responsible, or can the effect be explained by factors such as increased encoding variability brought on by the type of elaboration involved in imagining the survival scenarios? Understanding this will increase understanding of the overall operation of human memory more generally, including the basis of dramatic memory improvement in certain situations. Based on this understanding, this project will additionally attempt to identify and investigate other ways in which memory for particular items might be improved over and above the improvement shown using well-established mnemonic techniques. 

The research team will investigate hypotheses concerning the possible proximate mechanisms that produce the enhanced memory in imagined survival situations. For example, survival processing may naturally lead to variable encodings, or connections to other things in memory, that benefit later retrieval. To test this hypothesis, experiments are proposed that limit (or not) the extent to which people can use variable encodings to aid retrieval after survival-based processing. In addition to attempting to identify the proximate mechanisms of the survival processing effect, the research team will also explore a new area by investigating the mnemonic consequences of potential imagined contamination--do people remember objects that are said to have been touched by a sick person better than those said to have been touched by a healthy person? Avoiding contamination is extremely relevant to survival, and preliminary research suggests that people preferentially remember potentially contaminated objects; thus, this is a promising new area to explore beyond survival processing.

por.por_cntn:
Identifying and understanding factors that improve human memory is one of the central aims of human memory research. This project investigated a recently discovered means of improving memory known as the survival processing effect. Thinking about an item in terms of its potential survival value in an imagined survival situation greatly improves memory for that item relative to other known mnemonic techniques. This project aimed to understand the mechanisms that contribute to the survival processing benefit. For example, much of the debate has revolved around the specifics of the ancestral survival scenario used in the original work. Therefore, it was essential to develop new ways of assessing adaptive memory in order to: (1) establish the generality of the mnemonic advantages, and (2) eliminate alternative accounts that are unique to a particular assessment procedure. The results of the project have shown conclusively that the survival processing benefit is not tied to a particular procedure but is quite general. Thus, identifying how memory can be used to solve adaptive problems relevant to survival and reproduction provides critical insight into how human memory systems work and why they were formed.

Throughout the project, new topics were explored under the assumption that memory works in the service of survival and reproduction, which are two critical aspects underpinning human evolution. For example, we investigated the mnemonic consequences of potential contamination: Do people remember objects that are said to have been touched by a sick person better than those said to have been touched by a healthy person? Avoiding contamination is extremely relevant to survival, and our results showed that people preferentially remember potentially contaminated objects. We have also conducted research on the topic of reproduction: Is memory performance enhanced when information is processed in a context that is relevant to our chances of finding and securing a potential mate partner? Again, the mating context led to better long-term retention. These results provide additional strong support for the idea that our memory systems are “tuned” to problems relevant to survival and reproduction.

One significant result of this grant was the development of three new empirical procedures for studying adaptive memory: a choice procedure, a generation procedure, and one that requires people to remember the adaptive value of a target event. Each provides a novel way to study adaptive effects and helps to eliminate alternative accounts of the main empirical benefits. We have used these paradigms to explore the survival processing advantage but also to investigate the effects of potential contamination and of reproduction-related situations. We have collected evidence that significant memory improvements can be found after processing information in each of these three domains using each of the novel paradigms that we developed. Additionally, these new procedures can be used to investigate other topics in memory research in order to help us better understand memory functioning. For example, as part of the project we investigated ways in which insights about adaptive memory can be translated into improving performance in the classroom and in various training contexts.
